problem:
Let $a,$ $b,$ $c$ be the roots of $x^3 + px + q = 0.$  Express
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix}\]in terms of $p$ and $q.$
all_solutions:
To solve this problem, we can start by expanding the given determinant using cofactor expansion. We can expand it along the first column.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} = (1+a) \begin{vmatrix} 1+b & 1 \\ 1 & 1+c \end{vmatrix} - 1\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1+c \end{vmatrix} + 1\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1+b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix}\]

Now, we need to calculate each of these smaller determinants.

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1+b & 1 \\ 1 & 1+c \end{vmatrix} = (1+b)(1+c) - 1\]

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1+c \end{vmatrix} = 1(1+c) - 1\]

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1+b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1(1) - (1+b)\]

Substituting the values back into our expanded determinant, we have:

\[(1+a)[(1+b)(1+c) - 1] - 1(1+c - 1) + 1(1-b)\]

Simplifying this expression, we get:

\[(1+a)(1+b+c+bc) - 1-c + 1 - b\]

Expanding further, we have:

\[1+a+b+c+ab+bc+ac+abc - 1 -c - b\]

Cancelling out terms, we have:

\[a+b+c+ab+bc+ac+abc\]

Now, we know from Vieta's formulas for cubic equations that:
- The sum of the roots, $a+b+c = 0.$
- The sum of all possible products of two roots at a time, $ab + ac + bc = p.$
- The product of the roots, $abc = -q.$

Substituting these values, we have:

\[0+p-q\]

This expression simplifies to:

\[p-q = \boxed{p - q}\]

To evaluate the given determinant, we will expand it along the first row. 

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix}\]

Expanding along the first row, we have:

\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} &= (1+a)\begin{vmatrix}1+b&1\\1&1+c\end{vmatrix}-1\begin{vmatrix}1&1\\1&1+c\end{vmatrix}+1\begin{vmatrix}1&1+b\\1&1\end{vmatrix}\\
&= (1+a)[(1+b)(1+c)-1] - [1\cdot(1+c) - 1\cdot1] + [1\cdot1 - 1\cdot(1+b)]\\
&= (1+a)[1+b+c+bc] - (1+c) + (1 - 1 - b)\\
&= (1+a)[1+b+c+bc] - (1+c) - b\\
&= 1+ a + ab + ac + bc + b + c + abc - b - c - 1\\
&= a + ab + ac + bc + abc
\end{align*}

Now, we need to express the result in terms of $p$ and $q.$  Since $a, b,$ and $c$ are the roots of the cubic $x^3+px+q=0,$ by Vieta's formulas, we have

\begin{align*}
a+b+c&=0,\\
ab+ac+bc&=p,\\
abc&=-q.
\end{align*}

Substituting these values into the result, we obtain

\begin{align*}
a + ab + ac + bc + abc &= a + [ab + ac + bc] + abc\\
&= a + p + (-q)\\
&= a + p - q\\
&= \boxed{a - q + p}
\end{align*}

To finish off, we observe that $a$ is the root of the equation $a^3+pa+q=0.$  Thus,

\begin{align*}
a^3 + pa + q &= 0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^3 + pa &= -q\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a(a^2+p)&= -q\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^2p+p^2 +aq &= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^2p+p^2 +q(a)&= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad p(a^2+1)+q(a)&= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad (a^2+1)p+aq &= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad q(a^2+1)p+q(a) &= -q^2+q(a^2+1)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad q(a^2+1)p+q(a) &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a((a^2+1)p+q) &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquare a(a^2+1)p+aq &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquare a((a^2+1)p+q) &= q(a+1-p)\\
\end{align*}
This clearly shows that we needed to substitute this factorization of the value of "a" into our prior solution in order to make our prior claims true:
 \begin{align*}a^2p + aq + p^2 &= a(a^2+1)p+aq=aq(a+1)+aq\\&=q(a^2+2a+1)=q((a+1)^2) \end{align*}
Therefore: $a^2p + p^2 + aq = -q^2$,
    \begin{align*}a\left(a^2p + p^2 + aq \right) &= -q^2a\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p +ap^2 + a^2q &= -q^2a\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p+ap^2+q(a^2+1) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p+ap^2+pa^2+q &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+ap^2+q &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+q(ap^2+1) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+q(a^3+1) &= -q^2\\
    \end{align*}
So naturally, $ap^2 + a^3 + q= -q^2-a^2(p+q)$

    \begin{align*}a(ap+1)(a^2+1)+q &= -q^2-a^2(p+q)\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a(ap+1)(a^2+1)+q+a^2(p+q) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad (a^2+1+ap)(ap+1)+q &= -q^2-a^2(p+q)\\
    \end{align*}
So naturally, $(a^2+1+ap)(ap+1) +q = (a+1)(a^2+ap+1)+q = (a+1)(ap(a+1)+1) + q = (a+1)^2ap+1+a+q$
We can notice that we needed to use the substitution $(a+1)^2 = a^2+2a+1$
and
$(a+1)^3 = a^3 + 3a^2+3a+1$
where
\begin{align*}(a^2+2a+1)^3 &= (a^2+2a+1)^2\cdot(a^2+2a+1)\\
&= (a^4+4a^3+6a^2+4a+1)(a^2+2a+1)\\
&= a^6+4a^5+10a^4+12a^3+6a^2+a^4+8a^3+12a^2+8a+ a^2+4a+1\\
&= a^6+4a^5+11a^4+20a^3+17a^2+12a+1\\
&= (a^6 + 4a^5+4a^5)+(11a^4 + 20a^3+16a^3)+ (17a^2 + 12a\\&\;\;\;\;+ a^2) + 11a+1\\
&= a^5(a^1+4)+(4a^5)+(a^3)(11+5)+(4a^3) + (a^2)(16+1)+(4a) + (2a+1)(\frac{1}{2}a+\frac{1}{2}a+\frac{1}{2}a+1)\\
&= a^5(a+4)+(4a^5)+(a^3)(16)+(4a^3)(a^2)+(a^2)(17)+(4a) + (2a+1)((a+1)^2)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^5(a+4+4)+(4a^5)+16a^3+(4a^3a^2)+(17a^2)+4a+(2a+1)(a^2+2a+1) &= a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+20a^5+20a^4+17a^3+21a^2+8a+2a+1 &= a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+(20-18)a^5+(20-20)a^4+(17-17)a^3+(21-17)a^2+(8+2-4)a+2+1&=a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+2a^5+0a^4+0a^3+4a^2+6a+3&=a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1
model_solution:
To evaluate the given determinant, we will expand it along the first row. 

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix}\]

Expanding along the first row, we have:

\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} &= (1+a)\begin{vmatrix}1+b&1\\1&1+c\end{vmatrix}-1\begin{vmatrix}1&1\\1&1+c\end{vmatrix}+1\begin{vmatrix}1&1+b\\1&1\end{vmatrix}\\
&= (1+a)[(1+b)(1+c)-1] - [1\cdot(1+c) - 1\cdot1] + [1\cdot1 - 1\cdot(1+b)]\\
&= (1+a)[1+b+c+bc] - (1+c) + (1 - 1 - b)\\
&= (1+a)[1+b+c+bc] - (1+c) - b\\
&= 1+ a + ab + ac + bc + b + c + abc - b - c - 1\\
&= a + ab + ac + bc + abc
\end{align*}

Now, we need to express the result in terms of $p$ and $q.$  Since $a, b,$ and $c$ are the roots of the cubic $x^3+px+q=0,$ by Vieta's formulas, we have

\begin{align*}
a+b+c&=0,\\
ab+ac+bc&=p,\\
abc&=-q.
\end{align*}

Substituting these values into the result, we obtain

\begin{align*}
a + ab + ac + bc + abc &= a + [ab + ac + bc] + abc\\
&= a + p + (-q)\\
&= a + p - q\\
&= \boxed{a - q + p}
\end{align*}

To finish off, we observe that $a$ is the root of the equation $a^3+pa+q=0.$  Thus,

\begin{align*}
a^3 + pa + q &= 0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^3 + pa &= -q\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a(a^2+p)&= -q\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^2p+p^2 +aq &= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^2p+p^2 +q(a)&= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad p(a^2+1)+q(a)&= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad (a^2+1)p+aq &= -q^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad q(a^2+1)p+q(a) &= -q^2+q(a^2+1)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad q(a^2+1)p+q(a) &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a((a^2+1)p+q) &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquare a(a^2+1)p+aq &= q(a^2+1-p)\\
\Rightarrow\qquare a((a^2+1)p+q) &= q(a+1-p)\\
\end{align*}
This clearly shows that we needed to substitute this factorization of the value of "a" into our prior solution in order to make our prior claims true:
 \begin{align*}a^2p + aq + p^2 &= a(a^2+1)p+aq=aq(a+1)+aq\\&=q(a^2+2a+1)=q((a+1)^2) \end{align*}
Therefore: $a^2p + p^2 + aq = -q^2$,
    \begin{align*}a\left(a^2p + p^2 + aq \right) &= -q^2a\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p +ap^2 + a^2q &= -q^2a\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p+ap^2+q(a^2+1) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^3p+ap^2+pa^2+q &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+ap^2+q &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+q(ap^2+1) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a^2(p+q)+q(a^3+1) &= -q^2\\
    \end{align*}
So naturally, $ap^2 + a^3 + q= -q^2-a^2(p+q)$

    \begin{align*}a(ap+1)(a^2+1)+q &= -q^2-a^2(p+q)\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad a(ap+1)(a^2+1)+q+a^2(p+q) &= -q^2\\
    \Rightarrow\qquad (a^2+1+ap)(ap+1)+q &= -q^2-a^2(p+q)\\
    \end{align*}
So naturally, $(a^2+1+ap)(ap+1) +q = (a+1)(a^2+ap+1)+q = (a+1)(ap(a+1)+1) + q = (a+1)^2ap+1+a+q$
We can notice that we needed to use the substitution $(a+1)^2 = a^2+2a+1$
and
$(a+1)^3 = a^3 + 3a^2+3a+1$
where
\begin{align*}(a^2+2a+1)^3 &= (a^2+2a+1)^2\cdot(a^2+2a+1)\\
&= (a^4+4a^3+6a^2+4a+1)(a^2+2a+1)\\
&= a^6+4a^5+10a^4+12a^3+6a^2+a^4+8a^3+12a^2+8a+ a^2+4a+1\\
&= a^6+4a^5+11a^4+20a^3+17a^2+12a+1\\
&= (a^6 + 4a^5+4a^5)+(11a^4 + 20a^3+16a^3)+ (17a^2 + 12a\\&\;\;\;\;+ a^2) + 11a+1\\
&= a^5(a^1+4)+(4a^5)+(a^3)(11+5)+(4a^3) + (a^2)(16+1)+(4a) + (2a+1)(\frac{1}{2}a+\frac{1}{2}a+\frac{1}{2}a+1)\\
&= a^5(a+4)+(4a^5)+(a^3)(16)+(4a^3)(a^2)+(a^2)(17)+(4a) + (2a+1)((a+1)^2)\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^5(a+4+4)+(4a^5)+16a^3+(4a^3a^2)+(17a^2)+4a+(2a+1)(a^2+2a+1) &= a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+20a^5+20a^4+17a^3+21a^2+8a+2a+1 &= a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+(20-18)a^5+(20-20)a^4+(17-17)a^3+(21-17)a^2+(8+2-4)a+2+1&=a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a^6+2a^5+0a^4+0a^3+4a^2+6a+3&=a^6+18a^5+20a^4+17a^3+17a^2+4a+2a^2+4a+1
critique:
The best solution is Solution 1. 

The index number of the best solution is 1.
solution:
We can expand the determinant as follows:
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 + a & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} &= (1 + a) \begin{vmatrix} 1 + b & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + c \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + b \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (1 + a)((1 + b)(1 + c) - 1) - ((1)(1 + c) - 1) + (1 - (1 + b)) \\
&= abc + ab + ac + bc.
\end{align*}By Vieta's formulas, $ab + ac + bc = p$ and $abc = -q,$ so
\[abc + ab + ac + bc = \boxed{p - q}.\]
